elements.content: Two new pressure-dependent pseudo-polymorphism complexes, a 2D polymeric {[Cu2(TBA)]·2H2O} n (1) and a dinuclear [Cu2(TBA)(H2O)2]·2H2O (2), were successfully obtained and demonstrated to possess weak antiferromagnetic properties. The synthesis has been achieved through a novel one-pot reaction where four DMBA (DMBA = 1,3-dimethyl-barbitiric acid) molecules tetramerized in situ with EtOH to give (TBA)4– (H4TBA = 1,1′,2,2′-tetra-barbiturate-ethene) ligand. This unprecedented tetramerization involves one-pot formation of one new CC bond and four new C–C bonds. It was shown that the formation of 1 strictly relied on the use of Cu(II) ion and EtOH and that reactions of oxidation, Knoevenagel condensation, and Michael addition probably induce the tetramerization.

This unprecedented tetramerization involves one-pot formation of one new CC bond and four new C-C bonds. It was shown that the formation of 1 strictly relied on the use of Cu(II) ion and EtOH and that reactions of oxidation, Knoevenagel condensation, and Michael addition probably induce the tetramerization.

elements.content: The pressure-dependent pseudo-polymorphism complexes of the 2D polymeric network of 1 and the dinuclear structure of 2 have been obtained through the one-pot reaction, involving the formation of one new CC bond, four new C−C bonds, and two new tetrasubstituted carbon centers. This in situ reaction should strictly be relied on the raw materials and pressure, and may provide new insights for the bond-forming reaction in the future.

elements.content: Recently there has been significant interest in the synthetic chemistry of 1,3-dimethylbarbituric acid (DMBA), not only because of the variation of its derivatives but also due to the diverse applications for the derivatives including hypnotics, sedatives, soporifics, anticancer agents, or anti-AIDS agents. Organic synthesis reactions are primarily dependent on the C-5 reactive activity of DMBA often using a Knoevenagel condensation with aldehyde/ketone or Michael addition with α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds to produce the 5-alkylated or cyclizated organic products. By using a combination of Knoevenagel condensation and Michael addition, the dimerized or even trimerized organic derivatives are obtained. The coordination of the derivatives of DMBA relies on the electrophilic O atoms of OC groups from barbiturate rings. The existence of multiple carbonyl groups of the derivatives of DMBA, with varied coordination modes, makes the obtained complexes more complicated. However, on the basis of the careful review of the literature, an in situ tetramerized ligand synthesized from DMBA coupled by the newly formed carbon skeleton has never been reported before. On the basis of the one-pot synthesis, the metal-mediated catalytic reaction mechanism may further be revealed as well as the isolation of new products.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently there has been significant interest in the synthetic chemistry of 1,3-dimethylbarbituric acid (DMBA), not only because of the variation of its derivatives but also due to the diverse applications for the derivatives including hypnotics, sedatives, soporifics, anticancer agents, or anti-AIDS agents. Organic synthesis reactions are primarily dependent on the C-5 reactive activity of DMBA often using a Knoevenagel condensation with aldehyde/ketone or Michael addition with α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds to produce the 5-alkylated or cyclizated organic products. By using a combination of Knoevenagel condensation and Michael addition, the dimerized or even trimerized organic derivatives are obtained. The coordination of the derivatives of DMBA relies on the electrophilic O atoms of OC groups from barbiturate rings. The existence of multiple carbonyl groups of the derivatives of DMBA, with varied coordination modes, makes the obtained complexes more complicated. However, on the basis of the careful review of the literature, an in situ tetramerized ligand synthesized from DMBA coupled by the newly formed carbon skeleton has never been reported before. On the basis of the one-pot synthesis, the metal-mediated catalytic reaction mechanism may further be revealed as well as the isolation of new products.

elements.content: Herein we report the use of a simple system of DMBA, Cu2+ ion, and EtOH in the presence of Et3N, by the hydrothermal method or 10 kpa pressure control procedure to explore the formation of new coordination complexes from the in situ ligand synthesis of (TBA)4–. Two new complexes, a 2D polymeric {[Cu2(TBA)]·2H2O} n (1) and a dinuclear [Cu2(TBA)(H2O)2]·2H2O (2), were obtained in which the same building block of [Cu2(TBA)] from one tetramerized (TBA)4– ligand of four DMBA molecules on a new CC bond linkage with two Cu(II) ion, leads to the typical pseudo-polymorphism. The possible reaction mechanism on the in situ ligand synthesis, together with the magnetic properties of the two complexes, is also discussed.
elements.clean_text: Herein we report the use of a simple system of DMBA, Cu2+ ion, and EtOH in the presence of Et3N, by the hydrothermal method or 10 kpa pressure control procedure to explore the formation of new coordination complexes from the in situ ligand synthesis of (TBA)4-. Two new complexes, a 2D polymeric {[Cu2(TBA)]⋅2H2O} n  (1) and a dinuclear [Cu2(TBA)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2), were obtained in which the same building block of [Cu2(TBA)] from one tetramerized (TBA)4- ligand of four DMBA molecules on a new CC bond linkage with two Cu(II) ion, leads to the typical pseudo-polymorphism. The possible reaction mechanism on the in situ ligand synthesis, together with the magnetic properties of the two complexes, is also discussed.

elements.content: All commercially available materials and reagents were of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses of the compounds were obtained from an Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 using a Bruker Vector 22 FT TR spectrophotometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) investigation was recorded on a D/Max-IIIA diffractmeter with graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The data of magnetic susceptibility was collected using the Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL magnetometer from a polycrystalline sample at an external field of 1000 Oe with the temperature from 1.8 to 300 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All commercially available materials and reagents were of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses of the compounds were obtained from an Elementar Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 using a Bruker Vector 22 FT TR spectrophotometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) investigation was recorded on a D/Max-IIIA diffractmeter with graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The data of magnetic susceptibility was collected using the Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL magnetometer from a polycrystalline sample at an external field of 1000 Oe with the temperature from 1.8 to 300 K.

elements.content: To an aqueous solution (5 mL) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (72.5 mg, 0.3 mmol), a solution of 1,3-dimethyl-barbituric acid (DMBA, 47.0 mg, 0.3 mmol) in absolute EtOH (5 mL) and triethylamine (42 μL, 0.3 mmol) were added, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then the resultant deep blue solution was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 110 °C for 3 days. The mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.5 °C/h. The dark green block single crystals of complex 1 were obtained. Yield: 42 mg (70% based on DMBA). Elemental Anal. Calcd (%) for C26H28Cu2N8O14: C, 38.86; H, 3.51; N, 13.94. Synthesis of {[Cu2(TBA)]⋅2H2O} n  (1) from the Hydrothermal Method

To an aqueous solution (5 mL) of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (72.5 mg, 0.3 mmol), a solution of 1,3-dimethyl-barbituric acid (DMBA, 47.0 mg, 0.3 mmol) in absolute EtOH (5 mL) and triethylamine (42 μL, 0.3 mmol) were added, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then the resultant deep blue solution was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 110 °C for 3 days. The mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.5 °C/h. The dark green block single crystals of complex 1 were obtained. Yield: 42 mg (70% based on DMBA). Elemental Anal. Calcd (%) for C26H28Cu2N8O14: C, 38.86; H, 3.51; N, 13.94. Found: C, 38.81; H, 3.59; N, 13.88. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 2936 (s), 2879 (s), 1656 (s), 1650 (s), 1644 (m), 1485 (m), 1274 (m), 1116 (m), 926 (m), 779 (w).

elements.content: A simple low-pressure control procedure was used for the preparation of complex 2, where one 25 mL two-necked round-bottomed flask equipped with one condenser, one magnetic stirrer, and one rubber seal was the reaction system (Figure 1S, ). The condenser was connected to the bottom of a 1 m height water column in order to give the reaction system an additional pressure (10 kpa). In the flask, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (72.5 mg, 0.3 mmol) and DMBA (47.0 mg, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in distilled water (5 mL). To the stirred solution, another solution of triethylamine (42 μL, 0.3 mmol) in absolute EtOH (5 mL) was added slowly at room temperature, and then the reaction mixture was further stirred under vigorous reflux for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the green block single crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 25 mg (39% based on DMBA). Elemental Anal. Calcd (%) for C26H32Cu2N8O16: C, 37.19; H, 3.84; N, 13.34. Found: C, 37.09; H, 3.95; N, 13.28. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3385 (s), 2976 (s), 2881 (s), 1659 (s), 1651 (s), 1645 (m), 1490 (m), 1288 (m), 1120 (w), 925 (m), 785 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu2(TBA)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2) from the 10 kPa Pressure Control Procedure

A simple low-pressure control procedure was used for the preparation of complex 2, where one 25 mL two-necked round-bottomed flask equipped with one condenser, one magnetic stirrer, and one rubber seal was the reaction system (Figure 1S, ). The condenser was connected to the bottom of a 1 m height water column in order to give the reaction system an additional pressure (10 kpa). In the flask, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (72.5 mg, 0.3 mmol) and DMBA (47.0 mg, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in distilled water (5 mL). To the stirred solution, another solution of triethylamine (42 μL, 0.3 mmol) in absolute EtOH (5 mL) was added slowly at room temperature, and then the reaction mixture was further stirred under vigorous reflux for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the green block single crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 25 mg (39% based on DMBA). Elemental Anal. Calcd (%) for C26H32Cu2N8O16: C, 37.19; H, 3.84; N, 13.34. Found: C, 37.09; H, 3.95; N, 13.28. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3385 (s), 2976 (s), 2881 (s), 1659 (s), 1651 (s), 1645 (m), 1490 (m), 1288 (m), 1120 (w), 925 (m), 785 (w).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collections of complexes 1 and 2 were performed on a Bruker Siemens Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) K. Data collection and reduction were performed using the APEX II software. Multiscan absorption corrections were applied for all the data sets using the APEX II program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXL-97 program package. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Crystallographic data for complexes 1 and 2 are listed in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table . CCDC numbers are and for complexes 1 and 2.

DMBA was chosen as a raw material for in situ ligand synthesis and the further construction of novel metal complexes due to the reactive activity at C-5 position. As shown in Scheme , the reaction of equimolar amounts of DMBA, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, and Et3N in EtOH–H2O mixed solvents produced the clear deep blue solution, from which complexes {[Cu2(TBA)]·2H2O} n (1) and [Cu2(TBA)(H2O)2]·2H2O (2) were isolated as green block single crystals by the typical hydrothermal method and the 10 kPa pressure control procedure, respectively. In both complexes, the novel tetramer H4TBA was in situ obtained by the C-5 coupling from a newly formed CC bond with four DMBA. The formation of a new carbon skeleton of tetramer H4TBA involved an unprecedented reaction type, which exceeds the previous recognition of DMBA. The difference of reaction conditions, especially the contrast between the self-pressurized hydrothermal synthesis and the 10 kpa pressure procedure, allowed the formation of pressure-dependent polymeric complex {[Cu2(TBA)]·2H2O} n (1) and dinuclear complex [Cu2(TBA)(H2O)2]·2H2O (2). It is worth noting that the open system, even under the reflux, did not produce either of the two complexes.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and the Click Reaction Mechanism

DMBA was chosen as a raw material for in situ ligand synthesis and the further construction of novel metal complexes due to the reactive activity at C-5 position. As shown in Scheme , the reaction of equimolar amounts of DMBA, Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, and Et3N in EtOH-H2O mixed solvents produced the clear deep blue solution, from which complexes {[Cu2(TBA)]⋅2H2O} n  (1) and [Cu2(TBA)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2) were isolated as green block single crystals by the typical hydrothermal method and the 10 kPa pressure control procedure, respectively. In both complexes, the novel tetramer H4TBA was in situ obtained by the C-5 coupling from a newly formed CC bond with four DMBA. The formation of a new carbon skeleton of tetramer H4TBA involved an unprecedented reaction type, which exceeds the previous recognition of DMBA. The difference of reaction conditions, especially the contrast between the self-pressurized hydrothermal synthesis and the 10 kpa pressure procedure, allowed the formation of pressure-dependent polymeric complex {[Cu2(TBA)]⋅2H2O} n  (1) and dinuclear complex [Cu2(TBA)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2). It is worth noting that the open system, even under the reflux, did not produce either of the two complexes.

elements.content: Naturally, it is of special interest to investigate the effect of other factors, such as types of cations or anions and solvent systems, on the one-pot bond-forming reaction. A series of similar hydrothermal synthesis experiments to that of complex 1 have been performed, and the results were summarized in Table . First, the Cu(II) salts with different anions (NO3 –, SO4 2–, OAc–, Cl–, or C2O4 2–) all generated the same product of complex 1 with a respective stable yield. Unfortunately, no expected similar reactions took place from the use of Cu(I) salts, or other transition metal and lanthanide metal ions, whereas the mixture of them with Cu(NO3)2·3H2O produced the lower yield of complex 1. These results showed that the in situ coupling reaction should be exclusive due to the use of Cu(II) ion. Moreover, the experiments from other solvents or EtOH-containing mixed solvent systems showed that the coupling reaction was also EtOH-dependent.

In summary, the possible reaction mechanism on the in situ tetramerization of DMBA should involve the following multiple organic transformations, as shown in Scheme . Acetaldehyde was obtained from the oxidation of EtOH in the presence of Cu(II) catalysts, and barbiturate C5-carbanion was formed under the condition of Lewis base (Et3N). The nucleophilic addition product between the in situ formed acetaldehyde and barbiturate C5-carbanion was further oxidized to the corresponding ketone, followed by the further nucleophilic addition reaction, giving the intermediate dibarbiturate (dimer). The dibarbiturate (dimer) was protonated to produce tertiary carbocation, as the dibarbiturate was difficult to be directly oxidized, and then rearranged with the loss of H+. Through the subsequent oxidation and nucleophilic additions, tribarbiturate (trimer) and tetra-barbiturate (tetramer) intermediates were formed, respectively. Finally, the intramolecular dehydration of the tetra-barbiturate allowed the formation of the final product of H4TBA. This highly atom-economic one-pot reaction involves the formation of one new CC bond, four new C–C bonds, and two new tetrasubstituted carbon centers.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that the complex {[Cu2(TBA)]·2H2O} n (1) crystallizes in the centro-symmetric monoclinic space group C2/c and exhibits a 2D network composed of the neutral coordination framework and H2O solvate molecules. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of complex 1 contains one Cu(II) ion, half unit of deprotonated TBA, and one H2O solvate molecule. The central Cu2+ ion (Cu1) lies in a five-coordinate environment and adopts the distorted square pyramidal geometry, where four O atoms (O2a, O3b, O4a, and O6b) from one in situ formed (TBA)4– act as the equatorial plane, the other O atom (O1) from another in situ formed TBA occupies the axial position of the coordination polyhedron. The Cu(1)–O(1) bond length (2.247(6) Å) is distinctively longer than those (1.990(7)–2.037(6) Å) with the other four O atoms from the equatorial plane. The distortion resulted from the trans-conformation of the in situ formed (TBA)4– along the C(7)C(7a) bond (1.225(2) Å), where four coplanar O atoms from each barbiturate ring chelated to the same Cu2+ ion (Cu1) while the vertex atom (O1) is not in the vertical. In the trans-conformational (TBA)4–, the dihedral angle of 97.1(2)° between the bidentate and tridentate barbiturate rings on the same side is observed. It is notable that this trans-conformation of (TBA)4– causes the same chelation to the nearby Cu2+ ion (Cu1a), resulting in the formation of a dimer building block with the Cu(1)···Cu(1a) distance of 4.962(2) Å. Through the coordination of residual atoms of two tridentate barbiturate rings of (TBA)4–, the further self-assembly of the building blocks generates an undulated 2D network (Figure ). The topology of the 2D network can be rationalized in terms of a 5-connected topology with the short (Schläfli) vertex symbol of (44·63) when Cu(II) ions are only considered as nodes (Figure ). The H2O solvate molecules are not bound to the framework, and they exhibit no observed interactions with the host structure.
elements.clean_text:
Description of the Crystal Structures of Complexes 1 and 2 

X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that the complex {[Cu2(TBA)]⋅2H2O} n  (1) crystallizes in the centro-symmetric monoclinic space group C2/c and exhibits a 2D network composed of the neutral coordination framework and H2O solvate molecules. As shown in Figure , the asymmetric unit of complex 1 contains one Cu(II) ion, half unit of deprotonated TBA, and one H2O solvate molecule. The central Cu2+ ion (Cu1) lies in a five-coordinate environment and adopts the distorted square pyramidal geometry, where four O atoms (O2a, O3b, O4a, and O6b) from one in situ formed (TBA)4- act as the equatorial plane, the other O atom (O1) from another in situ formed TBA occupies the axial position of the coordination polyhedron. The Cu(1)-O(1) bond length (2.247(6) Å) is distinctively longer than those (1.990(7)-2.037(6) Å) with the other four O atoms from the equatorial plane. The distortion resulted from the trans-conformation of the in situ formed (TBA)4- along the C(7)C(7a) bond (1.225(2) Å), where four coplanar O atoms from each barbiturate ring chelated to the same Cu2+ ion (Cu1) while the vertex atom (O1) is not in the vertical. In the trans-conformational (TBA)4-, the dihedral angle of 97.1(2)° between the bidentate and tridentate barbiturate rings on the same side is observed. It is notable that this trans-conformation of (TBA)4- causes the same chelation to the nearby Cu2+ ion (Cu1a), resulting in the formation of a dimer building block with the Cu(1)⋅⋅⋅Cu(1a) distance of 4.962(2) Å. Through the coordination of residual atoms of two tridentate barbiturate rings of (TBA)4-, the further self-assembly of the building blocks generates an undulated 2D network (Figure ). The topology of the 2D network can be rationalized in terms of a 5-connected topology with the short (Schläfli) vertex symbol of (44⋅63) when Cu(II) ions are only considered as nodes (Figure ). The H2O solvate molecules are not bound to the framework, and they exhibit no observed interactions with the host structure.

elements.content: Complex [Cu2(TBA)(H2O)2]·2H2O (2) crystallizes in the centro-symmetric monoclinic space group P2(1)/n, where its asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographic independent components. One Cu(II) ion, one-half unit of depronated (TBA)4–, and one H2O solvate molecule comprise each of the two almost equivalent components. As shown in Figure , each of the central Cu2+ ions (Cu1 or Cu2) also lies in a five-coordinate environment and adopts the distorted square pyramidal geometry, while the four O atoms (O1, O3a, O4, and O6a) from one in situ formed (TBA)4– constitute the equatorial plane, with the other O atom (O7) from the coordinated H2O molecule not from another in situ formed (TBA)4– as complex 1 at the vertex. The (TBA)4– also endows the trans-conformation, while the dihedral angle between the two barbiturate rings on the same side of the CC bond (1.265(12)–1.341(10) Å) is relatively smaller (82.4(2)°). The four barbiturate rings of (TBA)4– have a similar bidentate mode, from which the (TBA)4– also chelates two Cu(II) ions, leading to the formation of a simple discrete dimer structure with the Cu(1)···Cu(1a) or Cu(2)···Cu(2a) distance of 4.940(2) or 4.979(2) Å, respectively. A detailed examination of the crystal packing reveals that the dimer unit based on Cu1 and Cu1a ions connects its nearby same repeating unit from two kinds of complementary weak edge-to-face C10–O5···π (3.177(5)–3.692(6) Å) interactions, while two equivalent nearby dimer units from Cu2 and Cu2a ions connect with the typical C25–H25···O11 (3.306(7) Å) weak hydrogen bonds, leading to the formation of the respective 1D infinite chain. Each of the two nearby 1D chains is further linked by the complementary weak edge-to-face C5–H5···π (3.370(6) Å) interactions to provide the 2D supramolecular network, as shown in Figure . The H2O solvate molecules are not bound to the framework, and they also exhibit no observed interactions with the host structure.

elements.content: What is particularly noteworthy is the comparison of the inherent relationship between the structure of complexes 1 and 2 and the reaction procedure. If we ignore the coordinated H2O molecules in complex 2, the same molecular formula [Cu2(TBA)] was obtained from the two complexes. More importantly, the consistent dimer building blocks are responsible for the network formation due to the similar trans-conformations of (TBA)4–. Therefore, complexes 1 and 2 are the typical examples of the solvent-induced pseudo-polymorphism. However, the formation is pressure-dependent and not due to the usual change of stoichiometry and solvent. Furthermore, it can be presumed that the higher energy involved in the hydrothermal method should prompt more in situ formed (TBA)4– ligands to coordinate one Cu(II) ion, resulting in the formation of 2D polymer 1 from discrete dimer complex 2. The bulk phase purity of the two complexes was convincingly established by X-ray powder diffraction measurements. The diffraction patterns for complexes 1 and 2 are depicted in Figure 2S, , which demonstrates the close match between each of the observed and the corresponding calculated pattern, confirming that a single phase (greater than ∼95% purity) is formed for each complex.

If we ignore the coordinated H2O molecules in complex 2, the same molecular formula [Cu2(TBA)] was obtained from the two complexes. More importantly, the consistent dimer building blocks are responsible for the network formation due to the similar trans-conformations of (TBA)4-. Therefore, complexes 1 and 2 are the typical examples of the solvent-induced pseudo-polymorphism. However, the formation is pressure-dependent and not due to the usual change of stoichiometry and solvent. Furthermore, it can be presumed that the higher energy involved in the hydrothermal method should prompt more in situ formed (TBA)4- ligands to coordinate one Cu(II) ion, resulting in the formation of 2D polymer 1 from discrete dimer complex 2. The bulk phase purity of the two complexes was convincingly established by X-ray powder diffraction measurements. The diffraction patterns for complexes 1 and 2 are depicted in Figure 2S, , which demonstrates the close match between each of the observed and the corresponding calculated pattern, confirming that a single phase (greater than ~95% purity) is formed for each complex.

elements.content: Direct-current (dc) magnetic susceptibility studies were performed on single-crystal samples of complexes 1 and 2 at 1000 Oe in the temperature range of 1.8 to 300 K. As shown in Figures and , the χM T value at room temperature (300 K) for complexes 1 and 2 is 0.83 or 0.81 cm3·K·mol–1, respectively, close to the value (0.75 cm3·K·mol–1) for two uncoupled Cu(II) (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions. Indeed, the two χM T products at 1000 Oe remain roughly constant (0.83–0.81 cm3·K·mol–1 for 1 and 0.81–0.80 cm3·K·mol–1 for 2) from 300 K down to 7 K, temperature below which the χM T product starts to decrease with increasing abruptness to reach the same minimum value at 1.8 K of 0.78 cm3·K·mol–1. This thermal behavior, together with the almost similar pattern of χM vs T clearly indicates the presence of intramolecular antiferromagnetic interactions between two S = 1/2 Cu(II) spins due to the similar dimer unit in the two complexes. On the basis of the dinuclear copper(II) core topology, these systems can be viewed as an S = 1/2 spin dimer with the following Heisenberg spin Hamiltonian: H = − 2 J ( S Cu 1 · S Cu 2 ) where J is the CuII···CuII magnetic interaction and S i is the spin operator for the two CuII metal ions. The theoretical expression of the magnetic susceptibility can be estimated by applying the van Vleck equation in the weak field approximation: χ M = ( 1 − ρ ) 2 Ng 2 β 2 kT × 1 3 + e − 2 J / kT + Ng 2 β 2 2 kT ρ Very good fits of the experimental data have been achieved with J = −0.13094 cm–1, g = 2.0927, and ρ = 1.1% for 1 and J = −0.05455 cm–1, g = 2.0768, and ρ = 1.3% for 2, respectively. The negative sign of the two J values is consistent with the weak antiferromagnetic coupling. The reason for the amplitude difference of the exchange-coupling constants with the similar penta-coordinated Cu(II) involved in the two complexes should result from the relatively stronger coordination bonds linkage for complex 1 not from the weak supramolecular interactions for complex 2 in their 2D networks.

Magnetic Properties

Direct-current (dc) magnetic susceptibility studies were performed on single-crystal samples of complexes 1 and 2 at 1000 Oe in the temperature range of 1.8 to 300 K. As shown in Figures  and , the χM T value at room temperature (300 K) for complexes 1 and 2 is 0.83 or 0.81 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, respectively, close to the value (0.75 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1) for two uncoupled Cu(II) (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions. Indeed, the two χM T products at 1000 Oe remain roughly constant (0.83-0.81 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 for 1 and 0.81-0.80 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 for 2) from 300 K down to 7 K, temperature below which the χM T product starts to decrease with increasing abruptness to reach the same minimum value at 1.8 K of 0.78 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1. This thermal behavior, together with the almost similar pattern of χM vs T clearly indicates the presence of intramolecular antiferromagnetic interactions between two S = 1/2 Cu(II) spins due to the similar dimer unit in the two complexes. On the basis of the dinuclear copper(II) core topology, these systems can be viewed as an S = 1/2 spin dimer with the following Heisenberg spin Hamiltonian:  1  H = - 2 J  (   S   Cu 1   ⋅   S   Cu 2   )   where J is the CuII⋅⋅⋅CuII magnetic interaction and S i is the spin operator for the two CuII metal ions. The theoretical expression of the magnetic susceptibility can be estimated by applying the van Vleck equation in the weak field approximation:  2    χ   M   =  ( 1 - ρ )    2   Ng   2     β   2     kT   ×   1   3 +   e   - 2 J / kT     +      Ng   2     β   2     2 kT   ρ   Very good fits of the experimental data have been achieved with J = -0.13094 cm-1, g = 2.0927, and ρ = 1.1% for 1 and J = -0.05455 cm-1, g = 2.0768, and ρ = 1.3% for 2, respectively. The negative sign of the two J values is consistent with the weak antiferromagnetic coupling. The reason for the amplitude difference of the exchange-coupling constants with the similar penta-coordinated Cu(II) involved in the two complexes should result from the relatively stronger coordination bonds linkage for complex 1 not from the weak supramolecular interactions for complex 2 in their 2D networks.

elements.content: Through the self-assembly of DMBA, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, and Et3N in EtOH-H2O mixed solvents in a one-pot reaction, two pressure-dependent pseudo-polymorphism complexes of a 2D polymeric network of 1 and a dinuclear structure of 2 have been obtained. The 2D polymeric network of 1 and the dinuclear structure of 2 were produced from the hydrothermal and 10 kPa pressure control methods, respectively, involving the formation of one new CC bond and four new C–C bonds. Both the in situ formation of tetramer (TBA)4– from DMBA coupled by the carbon–carbon bonds and the formation course of this newly formed carbon skeleton are reported here for the first time. During the in situ formation of tetramer (TBA)4–, the reaction should strictly be relied on the use of Cu(II) ion and EtOH, while the multiple reactions mechanism of oxidation, Knoevenagel condensation, and Michael addition probably occurred. This result may provide a new synthesis route to higher oligomers from DMBA and also give new insights for the bond-forming reaction in the future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Through the self-assembly of DMBA, Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, and Et3N in EtOH-H2O mixed solvents in a one-pot reaction, two pressure-dependent pseudo-polymorphism complexes of a 2D polymeric network of 1 and a dinuclear structure of 2 have been obtained. The 2D polymeric network of 1 and the dinuclear structure of 2 were produced from the hydrothermal and 10 kPa pressure control methods, respectively, involving the formation of one new CC bond and four new C-C bonds. Both the in situ formation of tetramer (TBA)4- from DMBA coupled by the carbon-carbon bonds and the formation course of this newly formed carbon skeleton are reported here for the first time. During the in situ formation of tetramer (TBA)4-, the reaction should strictly be relied on the use of Cu(II) ion and EtOH, while the multiple reactions mechanism of oxidation, Knoevenagel condensation, and Michael addition probably occurred. This result may provide a new synthesis route to higher oligomers from DMBA and also give new insights for the bond-forming reaction in the future.

cln_elements.content:
To an aqueous solution (5 mL) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (72.5 mg, 0.3 mmol), a solution of 1,3-dimethyl-barbituric acid (DMBA, 47.0 mg, 0.3 mmol) in absolute EtOH (5 mL) and triethylamine (42 μL, 0.3 mmol) were added, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then the resultant deep blue solution was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 110 °C for 3 days. The mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1.5 °C/h. The dark green block single crystals of complex 1 were obtained. Yield: 42 mg (70% based on DMBA). Elemental Anal. Calcd (%) for C26H28Cu2N8O14: C, 38.86; H, 3.51; N, 13.94. Found: C, 38.81; H, 3.59; N, 13.88. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 2936 (s), 2879 (s), 1656 (s), 1650 (s), 1644 (m), 1485 (m), 1274 (m), 1116 (m), 926 (m), 779 (w).

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>2</sub>(TBA)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>) from the 10 kPa Pressure Control Procedure

A simple low-pressure control procedure was used for the preparation of complex 2, where one 25 mL two-necked round-bottomed flask equipped with one condenser, one magnetic stirrer, and one rubber seal was the reaction system (Figure 1S, ). The condenser was connected to the bottom of a 1 m height water column in order to give the reaction system an additional pressure (10 kpa). In the flask, a mixture of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (72.5 mg, 0.3 mmol) and DMBA (47.0 mg, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in distilled water (5 mL). To the stirred solution, another solution of triethylamine (42 μL, 0.3 mmol) in absolute EtOH (5 mL) was added slowly at room temperature, and then the reaction mixture was further stirred under vigorous reflux for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the green block single crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 25 mg (39% based on DMBA). Elemental Anal. Calcd (%) for C26H32Cu2N8O16: C, 37.19; H, 3.84; N, 13.34. Found: C, 37.09; H, 3.95; N, 13.28. IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3385 (s), 2976 (s), 2881 (s), 1659 (s), 1651 (s), 1645 (m), 1490 (m), 1288 (m), 1120 (w), 925 (m), 785 (w).
